text: who's your fellow travelers Marcos
Walter's world with the Charles de
Gaulle Airport here in Paris we just had
another great trip here and what I
thought I'd give you is kind of five or
six little tips are gonna help you have
a better time when you are here in
France and the first thing you should
know the first little tip I have is make
sure you know a little French when you
do come here no you don't have to be
fluent in French when you come here you
don't have to have huge conversations
but just knowing some of the basics si
vous play is please that's when you see
the SVP that means si vous plait please
another great one is miss T which is
thank you you always have to have that
but know those basic words because it
really makes a big difference when you
go around because it really opens up
people to like oh you're trying to speak
French they're gonna be a lot more
helpful because the people in France are
not as like horrible and mean and
unfriendly as they make them out in the
media the French people are fantastic
and you know a little French it really
goes a long way so that's the first
thing least know some basic words now
the second tip I have for you is have
patience when you come to France look
this place gets packed with tours so the
lines will be long if you're going to
the Louvre where you're going to some
Chateau in the Loire Valley or wherever
and so you got to make sure you have
patience but not just for the long lines
at tourist sites when you're going to go
buy things and pay for things sometimes
it takes a little time to get through
the lines you know don't be surprised if
the lady in front of you is talking to
the cashier for five minutes about their
day because they're friends and they're
chatting about things you will need some
patience for that
and with that patience also comes when
you eat when you go to dinner realize
that dinners going to take an hour maybe
two hours you're going to have like the
three-course meal kind of thing if you
have the menu so be ready for that and
also make sure learn led to see on the
bill because the bill doesn't just come
when you finish you've got to ask for it
it doesn't come right away when you ask
for it it takes some time after that so
make sure you have patience now the
third tip I have for you is think
compact when you come to France you need
to be compact in terms of your baggage
and all the stuff you have because when
you're going to be taking the trains
there's not always a ton of space for
the luggage and the things now if you're
taking the TGV fast trains yes there's
plenty of space we're going to be taking
a regional train or something like that
that overhead compartment probably will
hold more than
you know a purse or something like that
so you want to make sure you have small
bags and packed light also if you're to
be sitting in one of those Street side
cafes and doing things they might
actually pull the table out so you can
get in and then stick you in there with
the you know with the table behind you
so can't get quite tight and quite you
know stuff so if you're claustrophobic
just be ready for that the tight
quarters also the compactness also goes
in the hotel rooms they are smaller
hotel rooms you're not getting big giant
hotel rooms when you are here they are
rather small but just know it's okay
because you enjoy the rest of France so
much you won't care about the small
hotel rooms now the fourth tip I have
for you has to do with food the thing is
the food here in France is fantastic is
fantastic you will eat well I'm not
worried about that one thing I will say
though is if your hotel says oh well you
pay for breakfast it's like 10 euros for
breakfast or five years for breakfast
something like that you don't have to do
that because you can go to the local
bakery the patisserie or whatever and
get a croissant baguette for a fracture
that cos it'll be nice and fresh and you
can save a ton of money I know one hotel
we were at we had six people including
the kids and it was 10 euros per person
so it was like 60 euros for breakfast
and that's not worth it I went down the
next day I went down to the patisserie
the the bakery I got croissants fours I
spent 7 euros we all had a great meal so
make sure you do that that can save you
a lot of money also works for lunch or
dinner if you want to try to save a
little money just go to the store pick
up your bigots and cheese for a fraction
of the cost of going out for a meal now
the fifth tip I have is one of the ones
you should really know is that look
France it's more than just Paris you
need to go out and explore more than
just this beautiful city here in Paris
so if you want to go to the beaches and
the Riviera and lay out there in the Sun
or or see the lavender fields in the
Roman rooms and Provence or go to the
d-day beaches in Normandy or see the
chateaus in the WHA or go to Nazi I mean
there is so much beauty here in France
that don't limit yourself just to Paris
make sure you get out and what's cool is
they have great public transport here
that will take you all over the place
which will make it really easy for you
and also kind of like a little add-on to
that maybe a 6 tip if you're going to go
out and see the rest of the country you
can take the public transport pretty
much everywhere if you want to get to
the little small locations and off the
beaten tracks you will need to have a
your own car to do those things and I
will
say it's easy says take the train from
Paris to your destination if it's Avion
or
Kane or wherever take the train there
and then rent your car from that
location and have it to stay there
because it's easier to pick up and drop
off the car outside of Paris and then
you have to deal with Paris traffic
which can be really insane so those are
five or six little tips I have for you
for coming to France if you want to
learn more check us on our website at
Walters WorldCom and OV la from Charles
de Gaulle Airport in Paris bye
